channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ikata Journal: Warily Leading Japan’s Nuclear Reawakening
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe could soon return Japan to nuclear power, but first he needs the consent of remote towns like Ikata.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ikata Nuclear Power Station, which was idled after the 2011 disaster in Fukushima, is likely to be restarted soon to help bolster a recovery in Japan.

item.title: Ukraine Sets Deadline for Militias to Surrender Illegal Guns
item.description: So-called self-defense groups were ordered to disarm by Friday, the same day Ukraine is scheduled to sign the political articles of an association agreement with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Carnations in Independence Square in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital. Protest groups that helped oust the president are being asked to turn in unlicensed firearms.

item.title: Though High-Tech Tools Exist, Satellites Don’t Track Planes
item.description: The airline industry has sophisticated tools to follow planes and stream data from their flight recorders. But given cost and the general safety of air travel, neither the airlines nor regulators have adopted them.
item.dc:creator: By JAD MOUAWAD, CHRISTOPHER DREW and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Obama Steps Up Russia Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
item.description: President Obama also opened the door to more sweeping measures against core parts of the Russian economy, including the oil and natural gas industries.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER, ANNIE LOWREY and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: On Russia’s List for Sanctions, and Proud of It
item.description: Travel restrictions placed by Moscow on American officials like Senators John McCain and Mary L. Landrieu were accepted as a “badge of honor.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID S. JOACHIM

item.title: Bloomberg Hints at Curb On Articles About China
item.description: Comments from the chairman of Bloomberg L.P. represent the starkest acknowledgment yet by a senior Bloomberg executive that the ambitions of the news division should be assessed in the context of the business operation.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Peter T. Grauer, chairman of Bloomberg L.P., said being in China “occupies a lot of our thinking."

item.title: Israel Confirms Fate of 8 Jews Who Left Iran
item.description: The Mossad intelligence agency confirmed that the eight would-be immigrants were murdered when they disappeared in 1994, but did not say where or by whom.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Satellite Photos Send Jet Hunt to Southern Indian Ocean
item.description: Officials said that satellite imagery had detected objects that might be connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, and that planes and ships were sent to the remote area.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: This handout from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority shows the satellite images of the two objects that officials say could possibly be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Russia Hints at Using Iran Talks as Leverage
item.description: While the most recent round of nuclear talks with Iran was regarded as productive, Russia suggested that it might impede them later.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Syria’s War Fuels Rise of Asylum Seekers, U.N. Report Says
item.description: The number of people applying for asylum in industrialized countries rose in 2013 to the highest number in more than a decade.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: 5 Indian Men Are Convicted in Gang Rapes at Abandoned Mill in Mumbai
item.description: A case that illustrates the continuing effects of a 2012 fatal assault on a woman in a bus in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Settlement Plans Renew Palestinian Outrage
item.description: Revelations this week over Israel’s continuing construction plans for West Bank settlements renewed outrage among Palestinian leaders.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Gunmen Attack Luxury Hotel in Kabul Weeks Before Afghanistan Elections
item.description: Four men with pistols opened fire at the Serena Hotel complex, which is popular with foreign officials and prominent Afghans, wounding two people before being gunned down.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan police officers arrived at the scene on Thursday after an attack on a police station in Jalalabad.

item.title: The Lede: Ukrainian Nationalists Hand Russians Propaganda Coup With Video of Assault
item.description: By recording their own act of violence against a television executive, Ukrainian nationalist politicians delivered a propaganda coup to their enemies in Russia, who claim that mob rule prevails in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: At War Blog: What’s in Veterans Affairs’ $164 Billion Budget?
item.description: The secretary of veterans affairs wants the spending to expand health care access and other benefits to veterans, to clear a still-extensive backlog of disability claims and to end homelessness among veterans.
item.category: Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America
item.dc:creator: By JACOB W. SOTAK

item.title: Iranian Ship, in Plain View but Shrouded in Mystery, Looks Very Familiar to U.S.
item.description: Iran is building a nonworking mock-up of an American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that United States officials say may be intended to be blown up for propaganda value.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Karolina A. Martinez/U.S. Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Nimitz-class aircraft carrier U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln in April 2012. Iran is building a mock-up in one of its shipyards.

item.title: Lawrence E. Walsh, Prosecutor in Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 102
item.description: As an independent counsel, Mr. Walsh exposed the lawbreaking in the administration of President Ronald Reagan that gave rise to the Iran-contra scandal.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL A. LEWIS
item.media:description: Lawrence Walsh, the independent counsel in the Iran-Contra case, in 1987.

item.title: Syria Delivers Another Shipment of Chemical Weapons for Disposal
item.description: The shipment to the port of Latakia was the third delivery in a week, further evidence that Syria has stepped up the pace of its efforts.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Japan and North Korea Said to Agree to Formal Talks
item.description: Japan made the announcement as the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been trying to score a coveted diplomatic success.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Pistorius Plans to Sell His House to Cover Legal Costs, Lawyer Says
item.description: As he stands trial for the murder of his girlfriend, Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star, plans to sell the house where he admits shooting her, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Lede: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
item.description: Posts on the Facebook and YouTube accounts maintained by Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah support descriptions of him by friends as a man without extremist leanings in religion or politics.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 20
item.description: The Dalai Lama holding the hand of a leprosy-affected patient in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama, exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, holding the hand of a leprosy-affected patient during his visit to a colony in New Delhi.

item.title: European Officials Reach Deal on Failed-Bank System
item.description: The agreement, subject to approval by the European Parliament and national governments, would be a big step toward a banking union in the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Martin Schulz, the president of the European Parliament, outside the E.U. headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Upheaval Highlights E.U.’s Past Miscalculations and Future Dangers
item.description: The situation has only underscored Europe’s divisions and exposed the chasm between the bloc’s high-minded aspirations and the rough reality of geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrived in Brussels on Thursday for a summit meeting of European Union leaders.

item.title: U.N. Warns of Anti-Muslim Violence in Central African Republic
item.description: Navi Pillay, the human rights chief, also criticized the slow international response to what she said was a humanitarian catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
